default: (a) a {@item light crossbow|phb} and {@item crossbow bolts (20)|phb|20 bolts} or (b) any {@filter simple weapon|items|source=phb|category=basic|type=simple weapon}
(a) a {@item dungeoneer's pack|phb} or (b) an {@item explorer's pack|phb}

fluff.name: The Sorcerer
entries: The Pallid half-elf mutters an incantation under his breath, and his shadow comes alive, taking the form of a massive wolf. At his command the wolf pounces on his attacker, a foolish bandit, knocking him to the ground. The half-elf chants another incantation, and as pulsing green orbs of acidic energy forms in his hands as the bandit struggles in vain against the massive shadow-beast. The bandit lets out a piercing scream, filled with regret, as the two spheres of acidic energy fly towards him.

As the grass and trees smolder from the great dragon's fiery blast, the smoke clears to reveal a young man. His clothes burned away to reveal patches of golden scales. His eyes flash a fierce gold, and white jets of flame burst from his fingertips. The dragon reels from the impact, crashing into the dirt. He had underestimated this mortal, how had he come to wield power rivaling a dragon?

The young halfling girl ducked into an alleyway, quickly hiding the stolen loaf of bread under her cloak. Back in the market she had come from, chaos had broken out. She had attempted a simple enchantment, just enough to convince the baker to give her a loaf of bread for free, but her magic had other plans. As she whispered to the baker, a crack - like a bolt of lightning - could be heard throughout the market, and suddenly all the produce in the square spoiled. She cursed this power that caused her parents to abandon her to the streets. If she could only control this power she could do much to ease the suffering of other urchins like herself.

entries.name: Unexplained Powers
entries: Sorcerers are rare in the world, and it's unusual to find a sorcerer who is not involved in the adventuring life in some way. People with magical power seething in their veins soon discover that the power doesn't like to stay quiet. A sorcerer's magic wants to be wielded, and it has a tendency to spill out in unpredictable ways if it isn't called on.

Sorcerers often have obscure or quixotic motivations driving them to adventure. Some seek a greater understanding of the magical force that infuses them, or the answer to the mystery of its origin. Others hope to find a way to get rid of it, or to unleash its full potential. Whatever their goals, sorcerers are every bit as useful to an adventuring party as wizards, making up for a comparative lack of breadth in their magical knowledge with enormous flexibility in using the spells they know.

entries.name: Raw Magic
entries: Magic is a part of every sorcerer, suffusing body, mind, and spirit with a latent power that waits to be tapped. Some sorcerers wield magic that springs from an ancient bloodline infused with the magic of powerful beings or elemental energies. Others carry a raw uncontrolled magic within them, chaotic storms that manifest in unexpected ways.

The appearance of sorcerous powers is wildly unpredictable. Some arcane bloodlines produce exactly one sorcerer in every generation, but in other lines of descent every individual is a sorcerer. Most of the time, the talents of sorcery appear as apparent flukes. Some sorcerers can't name the origin of their power, while others trace it to strange events in their own lives. The touch of a celestial, the blessing of a djinni at birth, or the taste of water from a mysterious spring might spark the gift of sorcery. So too might the gift of a deity of magic, exposure to the elemental forces of the Inner Planes or the maddening chaos of Limbo, or a glimpse into the inner workings of reality.

Sorcerers have no use for the spellbooks and ancient tomes of magic lore that wizards rely on, nor do they rely on a patron to grant their spells as warlocks do. By learning to harness and channel their own inborn magic, they can discover new and staggering ways to unleash their power.

entries.name: Creating a Sorcerer
entries: The most important question to consider when creating your sorcerer is the origin of your power. As a starting character, you'll choose a sorcerous origin from the options detailed in the class description, but the exact source of your power is up to you to decide. Is it a family curse, passed down to you from distant ancestors? Or did some extraordinary event leave you blessed with inherent magic but perhaps scarred as well?

entries.name: Quick Build
entries: You can make a sorcerer quickly by following these suggestions. First, make Charisma your highest ability score followed by Constitution. Second, choose the {@background hermit} background. Third, choose the {@spell light}, {@spell prestidigitation}, {@spell ray of frost}, and {@spell shocking grasp} cantrips, along with the 1st-level spells {@spell shield} and {@spell magic missile}.

classFeature.name: Spellcasting
entries: An event in your past, or in the life of a parent or ancestor, left an indelible mark on you, infusing you with Arcane Magic. This font of magic, whatever its Origin, fuels your Spells. See {@book chapter 10|PHB|10} of the Player's Handbook for the general rules of Spellcasting and {@book chapter 11|PHB|11} for the {@filter sorcerer spell list|spells|class=Alternate Sorcerer (LLAS)}.

entries.name: Cantrips
entries: At 1st level, you know four cantrips of your choice from the {@filter sorcerer spell list|spells|class=Alternate Sorcerer (LLAS)}. You learn an additional sorcerer cantrip of your choice at 4th level and another at 10th level.

entries.name: Sorcery Points
entries: The Sorcerer table shows how many sorcery points you have to cast your spells of 1st-level and higher. To cast one of these sorcerer spells, you must expend the amount of sorcery points indicated in the table below. You regain all expended sorcery points when you finish a long rest.
For example, as a 3rd level sorcerer, you can cast the spell {@spell burning hands} at 2nd-level by spending 3 sorcery points.

entries.name: Spell Limit
entries: Your sorcerer leve limits the potency of spells that you can cast. This is reflected in the Spell Limit column of the Sorcerer Table. For example, as a 5th-level sorcerer, you are limited to casting spells of 3rd-level or lower.

entries.name: Spells Known of 1st-level and Higher
entries: You know two 1st-level spells of your choice from the {@filter sorcerer spell list|spells|class=Alternate Sorcerer (LLAS)}. The Spells Known column of the Sorcerer Table shows when you learn more sorcerer spells of your choice. Each of these spells must be of a level equal to your Spell Limit or lower. For instance, when you reach 3rd level in this class, you can learn one new spell of 1st or 2nd-level.

Additionally, when you gain a level in this class, you can choose one of the sorcerer spells you know and replace it with another spell from the sorcerer spell list, which also must be of a level equal to your Spell Limit or lower.

entries.name: Spellcasting Ability
entries: Charisma is your spellcasting ability for your sorcerer spells, so you use your Charisma whenever a spell refers to your spellcasting ability. In addition, you use your Charisma modifier when setting the saving throw DC for a sorcerer spell you cast and when making an attack roll with one.

entries.name: Spellcasting Focus
entries: Your magic comes from your body itself, you do not need a spellcasting focus to cast spells. However, you must have at least one free hand in order to cast spells that require somatic or material components.

entries.name: Spell Versatility
entries: Whenever you finish a long rest, you can replace one of your sorcerer spells of 5th-level or lower with another spell from the sorcerer spell list. The new spell must be the same level as the spell you replace.

classFeature.name: Sorcerous Origin
entries: At 1st level you choose your Sorcerous Origin, the source of your innate power. There are six origins detailed at the end of this class description; Aberrant Mind, Emberheart, Faeblood, Stoneblood, Stormsoul, and Waveborn.
Your choice grants you features when you choose it at 1st level and again at 6th, 14th, and 18th level.

entries.name: Origin Spells
entries: Each Sorcerous Origin has a list of origin spells that you gain at the sorcerer levels noted in the sorcerous origin description. These spells count as sorcerer spells for you, but they don't count against your number of Spells Known. Spells gained from this feature cannot be replaced.

entries.name: Alternate Sorcerous Origins
entries: Versions of the Draconic Bloodline, Wild Magic, Divine Soul, and Shadow Magic sorcerous origins that are compatible with the Alternate Sorcerer are presented at the end of this class description.

classFeature.name: Metamagic
entries: Starting at 2nd level, you can use your innate spark of magic to create your own specialized versions of the spells you cast. You learn two Metamagic options of your choice from the list below. You can use only one Metamagic option on a spell when you cast it, unless otherwise noted.

At the end of a long rest, you can choose to replace one of your Metamagic options with another of your choice. You learn an additional Metamagic option of your choice at 5th, 9th, 13th, and 17th levels.

classFeature.name: Sorcerous Restoration
entries: Upon reaching 3rd level, you regain expended power while resting. At the end of a short rest you can recover sorcery points equal to your sorcerer level. Once you use this ability you must complete a long rest before you can use it again.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 4th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM allows the use of feats, you may instead take a {@5etools feat|feats.html}.

classFeature.name: Sorcerous Origin Feature
entries: At 6th level, you gain a feature granted by your Sorcerous Origin.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 8th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM allows the use of feats, you may instead take a {@5etools feat|feats.html}.

classFeature.name: Font of Magic
entries: Starting at 10th level, you can use your inborn talent for arcane casting to spontaneously learn new spells. As an action, choose a sorcerer spell from your list of spells known, expend the sorcery points it would take to cast that spell, and replace it with a sorcerer spell of the same level.
Once you use this ability you must complete a long rest before you can use it again.

classFeature.name: Sorcerous Arcanum (6th level)
entries: At 11th level, your innate sorcerous power manifests as a Sorcerous Arcanum, a powerful arcane spell. Choose one {@filter 6th-level spell from the sorcerer spell list|spells|level=6|class=Alternate Sorcerer (LLAS)} as this arcanum. It does not count against your number of Spells Known.
You can cast your arcanum spell once, without expending sorcery points, and you regain all uses of your Sorcerous Arcanum when you finish a long rest.

At higher levels, you gain more sorcerer spells of your choice that can be cast in this way: one 7th-level spell at 13th level, one 8th-level spell at 15th level, and one 9th-level spell at 17th level.

When you cast your Sorcerous Arcanum spells you can apply a Metamagic you know to the spell as long as the spell is eligible. When you gain a level in this class you can replace one of your Sorcerous Arcanum spells with a spell of the same level from the sorcerer spell list.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 12th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM allows the use of feats, you may instead take a {@5etools feat|feats.html}.

classFeature.name: Sorcerous Arcanum (7th level)
entries: At 13th level, your innate sorcerous power manifests as a Sorcerous Arcanum, a powerful arcane spell. Choose one {@filter 7th-level spell from the sorcerer spell list|spells|level=7|class=Alternate Sorcerer (LLAS)} as this arcanum. It does not count against your number of Spells Known.
You can cast your arcanum spell once, without expending sorcery points, and you regain all uses of your Sorcerous Arcanum when you finish a long rest.

classFeature.name: Sorcerous Origin Feature
entries: At 14th level, you gain a feature granted by your Sorcerous Origin.

classFeature.name: Sorcerous Arcanum (8th level)
entries: At 15th level, your innate sorcerous power manifests as a Sorcerous Arcanum, a powerful arcane spell. Choose one {@filter 8th-level spell from the sorcerer spell list|spells|level=8|class=Alternate Sorcerer (LLAS)} as this arcanum. It does not count against your number of Spells Known.
You can cast your arcanum spell once, without expending sorcery points, and you regain all uses of your Sorcerous Arcanum when you finish a long rest.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 16th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM allows the use of feats, you may instead take a {@5etools feat|feats.html}.

classFeature.name: Sorcerous Arcanum (9th level)
entries: At 17th level, your innate sorcerous power manifests as a Sorcerous Arcanum, a powerful arcane spell. Choose one {@filter 9th-level spell from the sorcerer spell list|spells|level=9|class=Alternate Sorcerer (LLAS)} as this arcanum. It does not count against your number of Spells Known.
You can cast your arcanum spell once, without expending sorcery points, and you regain all uses of your Sorcerous Arcanum when you finish a long rest.

classFeature.name: Sorcerous Origin Feature
entries: At 18th level, you gain a feature granted by your Sorcerous Origin.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 19th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM allows the use of feats, you may instead take a {@5etools feat|feats.html}.

classFeature.name: Metamagic Mastery
entries: You are a manifestation of pure arcane power with virtually limitless potential. Arcane magic bends to your whims, and you can fundamentally alter spells at-will. Upon reaching 20th level you can apply any number of Metamagic options to a spell, as long as you have the sorcery points to do so, and the spell meets the requirements for the Metamagic.
In addition, your Metamagic options all have their sorcery point cost reduced by 1 (to a minimum of 1).

subclassFeature.name: Aberrant Mind
entries: An alien influence has wrapped its tendrils around you, warping you in both body and mind. Perhaps a psychic splinter lodged in your psyche after you suffered domination by an aboleth. Maybe you were born somewhere tainted by the Far Realm, a planar blot that changed you forever. Or perhaps mind flayers kidnapped you, subjecting you to the nightmarish process of ceremorphosis—but the transformation failed and left you altered.

subclassFeature.name: Aberrant Magic
entries: Starting at 1st level, you learn additional spells when you reach certain levels in this class, as shown on the Aberrant Magic table. The spell counts as a sorcerer spell for you, but it doesn't count against the number of sorcerer spells you know. These can't be replaced when you gain a sorcerer level.

subclassFeature.name: Warped Being
entries: Starting at 1st level, your aberrant origin protects you from harm. Your body might have a coating of viscous slime, tough hide, scales, or an invisible psionic barrier (choose the form of protection when you gain this feature). Whatever form the protection takes, your AC equals 13 + your Dexterity modifier while you aren't wearing armor.
Additionally, the aberrant influence causes your hit point maximum increase by 1, and it increases by 1 again whenever you gain a level in this class.

subclassFeature.name: Psionic Sorcery
entries: Beginning at 6th level, when you cast a spell from your Aberrant Magic spell list, you can choose to cast it without any verbal, somatic, or material components.
You can use this ability a number of times equal to your Intelligence modifier (minimum of once), and you regain all uses of this ability when you finish a long rest.

entries.name: Psionic Sorcery
entries: With some adjustments, the sorcerer class is the best way to realize the fantasy of a psionic player character. To have the flavor fully match the mechanics of a psionic character in 5th edition, use the following optional rule:

entries.name: Intelligence Spellcasting
entries: Replace any instance of Charisma in the Sorcerer Class Features or Sorcerous Origin features with Intelligence. Your saving throw proficiency, Spellcasting ability, Multiclassing prerequisites, and any other Charisma features become Intelligence-based.

subclassFeature.name: Psychic Defenses
entries: Starting at 6th level, you gain resistance to psychic damage, and you have advantage on saving throws to resist being {@condition charmed} or {@condition frightened}.

subclassFeature.name: Revelation in Flesh
entries: Beginning at 14th level, you can unleash the aberrant truth hidden within your flesh. As a bonus action, you can spend 3 or more sorcery points to transform your body for 1 hour. For each 3 sorcery points you spend, you can gain one of the following benefits of your choice, the effects of which last until the transformation ends:

items: You gain a swim speed equal to your movement speed and the ability to breathe both air and water. Gills grow from your neck and your fingers become webbed.
You gain a fly speed equal to your movement speed and can hover. As you fly, your skin glistens with mucus.

Your body, along with any equipment you are wearing or carrying, becomes slimy and pliable. You can move through any space as narrow as 1 inch without squeezing, and you can spend 5 feet of movement to escape from nonmagical restraints or being {@condition grappled}.
Your eyes turn black or become writhing sensory tendrils. You are aware of the location of any hidden or invisible creature within a 60-foot radius of you.

subclassFeature.name: Warp Reality
entries: Upon reaching 18th level, you can become the focal point of a reality-warping anomaly. As an action, you can magically radiate a transparent, 20-foot radius aura for 1 minute. Creatures of your choice treat the aura as difficult terrain, and when they begin their turn inside the aura, they take {@dice 2d10} psychic damage.

As a bonus action, you can end the aura early. If you do so, you and a number of creatures up to your Intelligence modifier (minimum of 1) within the aura are teleported to a location that you are familiar with, up to 1 mile away. Each creature must appear within 20 feet of you and in an unoccupied space. Unwilling creatures must make a Charisma saving throw. On a failed save they are teleported against their will.
Once you use this feature, you must complete a long rest before you can use it again.

subclassFeature.name: Emberheart
entries: As an Emberheart sorcerer, you have inherited the volatile mood and keen mind of the Efreeti. You tend toward impatience and making snap judgments. Rather than hide your distinctive appearance, you exult in it. Nearly all Emberheart sorcerers, also known as fire genasi, are feverishly hot as if burning inside, an impression reinforced by flaming red, coal-black, or ash-gray skin tones.
How does your flaming soul effect your decisions? Are you a raging inferno, unable to be controlled? Or, do you resist the urges of your bloodline, seeking to master your power?

subclassFeature.name: Efreeti Magic
entries: Starting at 1st level, you learn additional spells when you reach certain levels in this class, as shown on the Efreeti Magic table. The spell counts as a sorcerer spell for you, but it doesn't count against the number of sorcerer spells you know. These can't be replaced when you gain a sorcerer level.

entries.name: Genasi, Race or Sorcerous Origin?
entries: A player character or NPC with ties to the elemental planes, or the descendent of Genies is ripe with storytelling potential. However, this is better represented as a Sorcerous Origin.

Much like the Draconic Bloodline, Genie heritage is a great origin story for an adventurer, especially in light of the official lore for genasi in Dungeons & Dragons 5th Edition. A dwarven Stoneblood sorcerer or a human Emberheart sorcerer are more flavorful and tell a better story then a standard earth genasi or fire genasi.

subclassFeature.name: Heart of Flame
entries: Beginning at 1st level your Efreeti heritage grants you certain benefits. You are resistant to fire damage and have advantage on saving throws to resist being {@condition charmed} or {@condition frightened}.

Your blood is infused with the magic of elemental fire. You can speak, read, and write Primordial. This allows you to understand and be understood by those that speak it's dialects: Aquan, Auran, Ignan, and Terran.

subclassFeature.name: Wildfire
entries: Starting at 6th level your inner flame begins to burn more intensely. When you reduce a creature to 0 hit points with a spell of 1st-level or higher that deals fire damage, you can cause the creature to explode. Creatures within 10 feet must succeed on a Dexterity saving throw or take fire damage based on the slain creature's size. On a successful save they take no damage.
Small creatures deal {@dice 1d6} fire damage, and for each size category above Small, the explosion deals an additional {@dice 1d6} damage. Tiny or smaller creatures produce no explosion.

subclassFeature.name: Kindle the Flame
entries: Starting at 14th level, your connection to the Elemental Plane of Fire strengthens, and your body is restored by flames. When you cast a spell of 1st-level or higher that deals fire damage, you regain hit points equal to your Charisma modifier + the level at which the spell was cast.

subclassFeature.name: Primordial Inferno
entries: Upon reaching 18th level, your blood burns with the intensity of Elemental Fire. You no longer need to eat, drink, or sleep, and you are immune to fire damage. When you take damage from a creature within 60 feet that you can see, you can use your reaction to rebuke them with Elemental Flame. The creature must make a Dexterity saving throw. On a failed save they take fire damage equal to your sorcerer level.

subclassFeature.name: Faeblood
entries: Every so often, a mortal catches the attention of a powerful lord or lady of the Fey. Often the object of affection or the offspring of this relationship is gifted arcane power beyond that of most mortal beings. However, these infatuations are often short-lived, and the mortals are left to learn to use their power with little supervision or instruction.

Whether you were born of such a relationship, grew up near a Fey Crossroads, or were chosen by a powerful Fey creature, you have been blessed with the changing and chaotic arcane power associated with the Feywild.

subclassFeature.name: Fey Magic
entries: Your link to the feywild allows you to learn spells normally associated with the druid class. When your Spellcasting or Font of Magic features let you learn a sorcerer cantrip or a sorcerer spell of 1st-level or higher, you can choose the new spell from the druid spell list or the sorcerer spell list. You must otherwise obey all the restrictions for selecting the spell, and it becomes a sorcerer spell for you.

Also at 1st level, you learn additional spells when you reach certain levels in this class, as shown on the Fey Magic table. The spell counts as a sorcerer spell for you, but it doesn't count against the number of sorcerer spells you know. These can't be replaced when you gain a sorcerer level, or by your Font of Magic feature.

subclassFeature.name: Heartsight
entries: Starting at 1st level, your connection to the fairy gives you heightened empathic abilities. As an action you can touch a creature and force them to make a Charisma saving throw. On a failed save, you learn the creatures alignment. Celestials, fiends, and undead automatically fail the saving throw. Creatures are not aware that you attempted to read their heart.
You can use this ability a number of times equal to your Charisma modifier (minimum of 1), and you regain all expended uses when you finish a long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Seasonal Attunement
entries: Beginning at 6th level, you gain the ability to align your soul with one of the four seasons, much like the denizens of the Feywild. At the end of a long rest you align yourself with one of the four seasons of your choice, and you gain the benefits of that season as detailed in the Seasonal Attunement table below. Each season grants you a resistance to one type of damage and advantage on certain rolls.

subclassFeature.name: Gateway Magic
entries: Starting at 14th level, you learn to briefly slip between the feywild and the material plane. Immediately after casting a spell of 1st-level or higher, can use your bonus action teleport to an unoccupied space within 30 feet that you can see.

When you use this ability you can choose to expend sorcery points to teleport further then normal. For each sorcery point you expend you can teleport an additional 5 feet beyond the normal 30 foot distance.

subclassFeature.name: Overchannel
entries: Upon reaching 18th level, your power rivals that of the Archfey themselves. When you cast a spell of 1st-level or higher, you can spend an additional number of sorcery points equal to the spells level and the spell deals maximum damage, instead of rolling.
Once you use this feature you must complete a long rest before you can use it again.

subclassFeature.name: Stoneblood
entries: As a Stoneblood sorcerer, or earth genasi, you are a descendant of the cruel and greedy Dao, unquestioned rulers of the Elemental Plane of Earth. You have inherited some measure of control over earth, their superior strength, and their solid power. The power that dwells within your blood urges you to dominate the weak willed, remain steadfast in your decisions, and hoard the fruits of the earth; precious gems, metals, and minerals.
Do you give in to the call of your bloodline? Or, do you seek to forge your own path? Though earth and stone may seem immovable, time can weather the strongest stone.

subclassFeature.name: Dao Magic
entries: Starting at 1st level, you learn additional spells when you reach certain levels in this class, as shown on the Dao Magic table. The spell counts as a sorcerer spell for you, but it doesn't count against the number of sorcerer spells you know. These can't be replaced when you gain a sorcerer level.

subclassFeature.name: Heart of Stone
entries: The influence of the Elemental Plane of Earth has hardened your body beyond its mortal limitations. Starting at 1st level, your hit point maximum increases by 1 and increases by 1 again whenever you gain a level in this class. In addition, when not wearing any armor or using a shield your armor class is equal to 13 + your Constitution modifier.

Your blood is infused with the magic of elemental earth. You can speak, read, and write Primordial. This allows you to understand and be understood by those that speak it's dialects: Aquan, Auran, Ignan, and Terran.

subclassFeature.name: Earthen Armament
entries: As a descendant of the Dao you have inherited their ability to manipulate the earth and stone to defend yourself. Starting at 1st level, you can use a bonus action to plunge your arm into any earth or stone and draw material from the Plane of Earth to create a weapon known as an earthen armament. This weapon has both the heavy and two-handed properties, and you are considered proficient with it. When you attack with your earthen armament you can use your Constitution modifier, in place of Strength, for attack and damage rolls, and it deals {@dice 1d12} bludgeoning damage on hit.
Your earthen armament lasts for one minute, or until you let go of it, at which point it dissipates into fine dirt or stone.

entries.name: Weapons of Stone
entries: The appearance of an earthen armament is chosen by the sorcerer when it is created, and is often a manifestation of their soul. Do you tap into your anger and pull forth crude stalagmites of stone? Or do you view each armament as a work of art, producing expertly crafted weapons?

subclassFeature.name: Heavy Blows
entries: Starting at 6th level, you can infuse your earthen armament with the crushing weight of the Elemental Plane of Earth. When you hit a creature with a your earthen armament you can expend sorcery points to deal force damage to the target, in addition to the weapon damage. The extra damage is {dice 2d6} for 2 sorcery points, plus {@dice 1d6} for each additional sorcery point you spend.
The maximum number of sorcery points you can expend on this ability is equal to half your sorcerer level, rounded down (minimum of 1).
In addition, attacks you make with your earthen armament count as magical for the sake of overcoming resistances.

subclassFeature.name: Aegis of Stone
entries: Beginning at 14th level, your connection to the Elemental Plane of Earth deepens. As a bonus action, you can expend 2 sorcery points and grant an aegis of protective earth magic to yourself, or one creature you can touch. The creature gains resistance to nonmagical bludgeoning, piercing, and slashing damage for 1 minute. If you use this ability again the effect immediately ends for the first creature.

In addition, when a creature hits the protected target with a melee attack, you can use your reaction to teleport to an unoccupied space within 5 feet of the attacker and make one melee weapon attack against them. You can teleport in this way only if you and the attacker are on the same surface.

subclassFeature.name: Primordial Bulwark
entries: Starting at 18th level, your being is altered by the power of Elemental Earth. You no longer need to eat, drink, or sleep, and you have permanent resistance to bludgeoning, piercing, and slashing damage.
In addition, you can use your Aegis of Stone to protect up to three creatures at one time.

subclassFeature.name: Stormsoul
entries: As a Stormsoul sorcerer, or air genasi, you are descended from the whimsical Djinni. As changeable as the weather, your moods shift from calm, to wild and violent, with little warning, but these storms rarely last long. It is in your blood to move like the wind, never staying in one place for long.
Do you give in to the tendencies of your Djinni ancestors, never taking anything, or anyone, seriously? Or do you resist the storm within, forging bonds and friendships?

subclassFeature.name: Djinni Magic
entries: Starting at 1st level, you learn additional spells when you reach certain levels in this class, as shown on the Djinni Magic table. The spell counts as a sorcerer spell for you, but it doesn't count against the number of sorcerer spells you know. These can't be replaced when you gain a sorcerer level.

subclassFeature.name: Heart of the Storm
entries: You have inherited certain properties from your Djinni ancestry. Starting at 1st level, you are under the effects of the {@spell feather fall} spell as long as you are conscious, and you can take the {@action Disengage} action as a bonus action on your turn.

Your blood is infused with the magic of elemental air. You can speak, read, and write Primordial. This allows you to understand and be understood by those that speak it's dialects: Aquan, Auran, Ignan, and Terran.

subclassFeature.name: Tempestous Magic
entries: Channeling your elemental power allows you to soar through the air, if only for a short duration. Starting at 1st level, you can use a bonus action on your turn to cause whirling gusts of elemental air to briefly surround you, immediately before or after you cast a spell of 1st level or higher. Doing so allows you to fly a number of feet equal to five times your Charisma modifier (minimum of 1). Flying in this way does not provoke opportunity attacks.

subclassFeature.name: Eye of the Storm
entries: Beginning at 6th level, the power of your Djinni blood becomes more apparent. You gain resistance to lightning and thunder damage.

In addition, whenever you start casting a spell of 1st-level or higher that deals lightning or thunder damage, stormy magic erupts from you. Creatures of your choice within 10 feet of you must make a Dexterity saving throw. On a failed save they take lightning or thunder damage (your choice) equal to half your sorcerer level.

subclassFeature.name: Storm Guide
entries: Upon reaching 6th level, your ties to the Elemental Plane of Air allow you to subtly control the weather around you.
If it is raining, you can use an action to cause the rain to stop falling in a 20-foot radius sphere centered on you. You can end this effect as a bonus action.

If it is windy, you can use a bonus action each round to choose the direction that the wind blows in a 100-foot radius sphere centered on you. The wind blows in that direction until the end of your next turn.

subclassFeature.name: Windcaller
entries: Upon reaching 14th level, you manifest the signature ability of the Djinni and become one with the air. You gain a fly speed equal to your movement speed. As you fly your lower extremities turn into a swirling whirlwind.

subclassFeature.name: Primordial Storm
entries: Starting at 18th level, your body and soul have gained the full power the Princes of Elemental Air. You no longer need to eat, drink, or sleep, and you are immune to lightning and thunder damage.

In addition, when you are hit by a melee attack, you can use your reaction to force the attacker to make a Strength saving throw. On a failed save the creature takes lightning damage equal to your sorcerer level and is pushed back 30 feet in a straight line. On a successful save they take half damage and are not moved.

subclassFeature.name: Waveborn
entries: The Primordial Sea, the Elemental Plane of Water, the source of all oceans, rivers, and lakes, and the home of the Marids. Without the life-giving effects of this plane there would be no rain, no water to help crops grow. But the great waters of the world are also dangerous; floods, hurricanes, and tidal waves strike with great and terrible power.

The lapping of waves, the spray of sea foam on the wind, the ocean depths—all of these things call to your heart. As a descendent of the noble collectors, the Marid, you exhibit their fierce independence, pride, and love of fine things.

subclassFeature.name: Marid Magic
entries: Starting at 1st level, you learn additional spells when you reach certain levels in this class, as shown on the Marid Magic table. The spell counts as a sorcerer spell for you, but it doesn't count against the number of sorcerer spells you know. These can't be replaced when you gain a sorcerer level.

subclassFeature.name: Heart of the Sea
entries: Starting at 1st level, your Marid heritage fundamentally alters the nature of your body. You gain the following abilities:

items: You can breathe both air and water
You have {@sense darkvision} out to a radius of 60 feet.
You gain a swim speed equal to your movement speed.
You are resistant to cold damage.

entries: Your blood is infused with the magic of elemental water. You can speak, read, and write Primordial. This allows you to understand and be understood by those that speak it's dialects: Aquan, Auran, Ignan, and Terran.

subclassFeature.name: Watery Curse
entries: Starting at 1st level, you can infuse your spells with the watery curse of the Marid. When you hit a creature with a spell that deals cold damage, forces movement, or reduces movement speed, you can choose to mark them with a watery curse. While the creature is cursed, anytime you deal cold damage, force them to move, or reduce their movement speed, it must make an additional Strength saving throw. On a failed save, its movement speed is reduced to 0 until the beginning of their next turn.

The watery curse lasts for one minute, until the target is reduced to 0 hit points, or you mark another creature with your watery curse. Upon cursing a new creature any previous watery curses immediately end.
You can use this ability a number of times equal to your Charisma modifier (minimum of once), and you regain all expended uses when you finish a long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Watery Defense
entries: Beginning at 6th level, you can defend yourself by assuming a watery form. As a reaction, when you are hit by an attack, you assume a watery form and gain resistance to bludgeoning, piercing, and slashing damage until the beginning of your next turn. As part of the same reaction you can move your full movement speed without provoking opportunity attacks.
You can use this ability a number of times equal to your Charisma modifier (minimum of once), and you regain all expended uses when you finish a long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Empowered Curse
entries: Starting at 14th level, your connection with the sea empowers your watery curse. When you deal cold damage, force a creature to move, or reduce the movement speed of a creature marked by your watery curse, you can force it to make a Constitution saving throw in place of the normal Strength saving throw. On a failed save they are {@condition restrained}.

They can repeat this saving throw at the end of each of their turns, on a success, they are no longer restrained. If a creature's saving throw is successful or the effect ends for it, the creature is immune to the restraining effect of your watery curse for the next 24 hours.

subclassFeature.name: Primordial Deluge
entries: Upon reaching 18th level, your body and soul are permanently altered by the power of the primordial sea from which you draw your power. You no longer need to eat, drink, or sleep, and you are resistant to bludgeoning, piercing, and slashing damage.
In addition, your watery defense turns any critical hit against you into a normal hit.

subclassFeature.name: Alternate Draconic Bloodline
entries: Your innate magic comes from draconic magic that was mingled with your blood or that of your ancestors. Most often, sorcerers with this origin trace their descent back to a mighty sorcerer of ancient times who made a bargain with a dragon or who might even have claimed a dragon parent. Some of these bloodlines are well established in the world, but most are obscure. Any given sorcerer could be the first of a new bloodline, as a result of a pact or some other exceptional circumstance.

subclassFeature.name: Dragon Ancestor
entries: At 1st level, you choose one type of dragon as your ancestor. The damage type associated with each dragon is used by features you gain later.
You can speak, read, and write Draconic. Additionally, whenever you make a Charisma check when interacting with dragons, your proficiency bonus is doubled if it applies to the check.

subclassFeature.name: Draconic Magic
entries: Starting at 1st level, you learn additional spells when you reach certain levels in this class, as shown on the Draconic Magic table. The spell counts as a sorcerer spell for you, but it doesn't count against the number of sorcerer spells you know. These can't be replaced when you gain a sorcerer level.

subclassFeature.name: Draconic Resilience
entries: As magic flows through your body, it causes physical traits of your dragon ancestors to emerge. At 1st level, your hit point maximum increases by 1 and increases by 1 again whenever you gain a level in this class.
Additionally, parts of your skin are covered by a thin sheen of dragon-like scales. When you aren't wearing armor, your AC equals 13 + your Dexterity modifier.

subclassFeature.name: Draconic Sorcery
entries: Beginning at 6th level, when you cast a spell that deals acid, cold, fire, poison, lightning, or thunder damage, you can use the Elemental Spell Metamagic without spending additional sorcery points, as long as you change the damage type of the spell to the damage type of your Draconic Ancestry.
You can use this ability a number of times equal to your Charisma modifier (minimum of once). You regain all uses of this ability when you finish a long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Elemental Affinity
entries: Starting at 6th level, when you cast a spell that deals damage of the type associated with your draconic ancestry, you can add your Charisma modifier to one damage roll of that spell. At the same time, you can spend 1 sorcery point to gain resistance to that damage type for 1 hour.

subclassFeature.name: Dragon Wings
entries: At 14th level, you gain the ability to sprout a pair of dragon wings from your back, gaining a flying speed equal to your current speed. You can create these wings as a bonus action on your turn. They last until you dismiss them as a bonus action on your turn.
You can't manifest your wings while wearing armor unless the armor is made to accommodate them, and clothing not made to accommodate your wings might be destroyed when you manifest them.

subclassFeature.name: Draconic Presence
entries: Beginning at 18th level, you can channel the presence of your dragon ancestor. As an action, you can spend 5 sorcery points to draw on this power and exude an aura of awe or fear to a distance of 60 feet For 1 minute, each hostile creature that starts its turn in this aura must succeed on a Wisdom saving throw or be {@condition charmed} (if you chose awe) or {@condition frightened} (if you chose fear) until the aura ends. A creature that succeeds on this saving throw is immune to your aura for 24 hours.

subclassFeature.name: Alternate Wild Magic
entries: Your innate magic comes from the wild forces of chaos that underlie the order of creation. You might have endured exposure to some form of raw magic, perhaps through a planar portal leading to Limbo, the Elemental Planes, or the mysterious Far Realm. Perhaps you were blessed by a powerful fey creature or marked by a demon. Or your magic could be a fluke of your birth, with no apparent cause or reason. However it came to be, this chaotic magic churns within you, waiting for any outlet.

subclassFeature.name: Tides of Chaos
entries: Starting at 1st level, you can manipulate the forces of chance and chaos to gain advantage on one attack roll, ability check, or saving throw. Once you do so, you must finish a long rest before you can use this feature again.

Any time before you regain the use of this feature, the DM can have you roll on the Wild Magic Surge table immediately after you cast a sorcerer spell of 1st level or higher. You then regain the use of this feature.

subclassFeature.name: Chaos Magic
entries: Starting at 1st level, you learn additional spells when you reach certain levels in this class, as shown on the Chaos Magic table. The spell counts as a sorcerer spell for you, but it doesn't count against the number of sorcerer spells you know. These can't be replaced when you gain a sorcerer level.

subclassFeature.name: Wild Magic Surge
entries: Starting when you choose this origin at 1st level, your spellcasting can unleash surges of untamed magic. Immediately after you cast a sorcerer spell of 1st-level or higher, roll a {@dice d10}. If you roll a number equal the level of the spell you cast, roll on the Wild Magic Surge table to create a random magical effect.
See the Player's Handbook for the {@table Wild Magic Surge|PHB|Wild Magic Surge table}.

subclassFeature.name: Bend Luck
entries: Starting at 6th level, you have the ability to twist fate using your wild magic. When another creature you can see makes an attack roll, an ability check, or a saving throw, you can use your reaction and spend 2 sorcery points to roll {@dice 1d4} and apply the number rolled as a bonus or penalty (your choice) to the creature's roll. You can do so after the creature rolls but before any effects of the roll occur.

subclassFeature.name: Controlled Chaos
entries: At 14th level, you gain a modicum of control over the surges of your wild magic. Whenever you roll on the Wild Magic Surge table, you can roll twice and use either number.

subclassFeature.name: Spell Bombardment
entries: Beginning at 18th level, the harmful energy of your spells intensifies. When you roll damage for a spell and roll the highest number possible on any of the dice, choose one of those dice, roll it again and add that roll to the damage. You can use the feature only once per turn.

subclassFeature.name: Alternate Divine Soul
entries: Sometimes the spark of magic that fuels a sorcerer comes from a divine source that glimmers within the soul. Having such a blessed soul is a sign that your innate magic might come from a distant but powerful familial connection to a divine being. Perhaps your ancestor was an angel, transformed into a mortal and sent to fight in a god's name.
Or your birth might align with an ancient prophecy, marking you as a servant of the gods or a chosen vessel of divine magic.

A Divine Soul, with a natural magnetism, is seen as a threat by some religious hierarchies. As an outsider who commands sacred power, a Divine Soul can undermine an existing order by claiming a direct tie to the divine.

In some cultures, only those who can claim the power of a Divine Soul may command religious power. In these lands, ecclesiastical positions are dominated by a few bloodlines and preserved over generations.

entries.subclassFeature: Favored by the Gods|Alternate Sorcerer|AlternateSorc|Divine Soul|AlternateSorc|1

subclassFeature.name: Divine Magic
entries: Your link to the divine allows you to learn spells normally associated with the cleric class. When your Spellcasting or Font of Magic features let you learn a sorcerer cantrip or a sorcerer spell of 1st-level or higher, you can choose the new spell from the cleric spell list or the sorcerer spell list. You must otherwise obey all the restrictions for selecting the spell, and it becomes a sorcerer spell for you.

Also at 1st level, you learn additional spells when you reach certain levels in this class, as shown on the Divine Magic table. The spell counts as a sorcerer spell for you, but it doesn't count against the number of sorcerer spells you know. These can't be replaced when you gain a sorcerer level, or by your Font of Magic feature.

subclassFeature.name: Favored by the Gods
entries: Starting at 1st level, divine power guards your destiny. If you fail a saving throw or miss with an attack roll, you can roll {@dice 2d4} and add it to the total, possibly changing the outcome. Once you use this feature, you can't use it again until you finish a short or long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Empowered Healing
entries: Starting at 6th level, the divine energy coursing through you can empower healing spells. Whenever you or an ally within 5 feet of you rolls dice to determine the number of hit points a spell restores, you can spend 1 sorcery point to reroll any number of those dice once, provided you aren't {@condition incapacitated}. You can use this feature only once per turn.

subclassFeature.name: Angelic Form
entries: Starting at 14th level, you can use a bonus action to manifest a pair of spectral wings from your back. While the wings are present, you have a flying speed of 30 feet. The wings last until you're {@condition incapacitated}, you die, or you dismiss them as a bonus action.
The affinity you chose for your Divine Magic feature determines the appearance of the spectral wings: eagle wings for good or law, bat wings for evil or chaos, and dragonfly wings for neutrality.

subclassFeature.name: Unearthly Recovery
entries: At 18th level, you gain the ability to overcome grievous injuries. As a bonus action when you have fewer than half of your hit points remaining, you can regain a number of hit points equal to half your hit point maximum.
Once you use this feature, you can't use it again until you finish a long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Alternate Shadow Magic
entries: You are a creature of shadow, for your innate magic comes from the Shadowfell itself. You might trace your lineage to an entity from that place, or perhaps you were exposed to its fell energy and transformed by it.

The power of shadow magic casts a strange pall over your physical presence. The spark of life that sustains you is muffled, as if it struggles to remain viable against the dark energy that imbues your soul. At your option, you can pick from or roll on the Shadow Sorcerer Quirks table to create a quirk for your character.

entries.caption: Shadow Sorcerer Quirks
rows: You are always icy cold to the touch.
When you are asleep, you don't appear to breathe (though you must still breathe to survive).
You barely bleed, even when badly injured.
Your heart beats once per minute. This event sometimes surprises you.
You have trouble remembering that living creatures and corpses should be treated differently.

subclassFeature.name: Eyes of the Dark
entries: From 1st level, You can see normally in darkness to a distance of 120 feet. Additionally, as a bonus action, you can spend 1 sorcery point to be able to see normally in magical darkness for 1 minute.

subclassFeature.name: Shadow Magic
entries: Starting at 1st level, you learn additional spells when you reach certain levels in this class, as shown on the Shadow Magic table. The spell counts as a sorcerer spell for you, but it doesn't count against the number of sorcerer spells you know. These can't be replaced when you gain a sorcerer level.

subclassFeature.name: Strength of the Grave
entries: Starting at 1st level, your existence in a twilight state between life and death makes you difficult to defeat. When damage reduces you to 0 hit points, you can make a Charisma saving throw (DC 5 + the damage taken). On a success, you instead drop to 1 hit point. You can't use this feature if you are reduced to 0 hit points by radiant damage or by a critical hit.
After the saving throw succeeds, you can't use this feature again until you finish a long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Beast of Ill Omen
entries: At 6th level, you gain the ability to call forth creature of darkness. As a bonus action, you can spend 5 sorcery points to summon a beast of ill omen to target one creature you can see within 120 feet of you. The beast uses the {@creature dire wolf|mm|dire wolf's} statistics, with the following changes:

items: The beast's size is Medium, and counts as a monstrosity.
It appears with a number of temporary hit points equal to half your sorcerer level
It can move through other creatures and objects as if they were difficult terrain. The beast takes 5 force damage if it ends its turn inside an object.
At the start of its turn, the beast automatically knows its target's location. If the target was hidden, it is no longer hidden from the hound.

entries: The beast appears in an unoccupied space of your choice within 30 feet of the target. It shares your initiative and takes its turn immediately after you. On its turn, it can move only toward, and make attacks against its target. Additionally, while the hound is within 5 feet of the target, they have disadvantage on saving throws against any spell you cast. The hound disappears if it is reduced to 0 hit points, if its target is reduced to 0 hit points, or after 5 minutes.

entries.name: Creatures of Shadow
entries: When you summon your beast of ill omen you determine its appearance. Like a wizard's familiar, the beast you conjure takes on a shape that reflects your inner self. An unhinged sorcerer may conjure an emaciated wolf, while an apathetic sorcerer may conjure an aloof feline creature.

subclassFeature.name: Shadow Walk
entries: At 14th level, you gain the ability to step from one shadow into another. When you are in dim light or darkness, as a bonus action, you can magically teleport up to 120 feet to an unoccupied space you can see that is also in dim light or darkness.

subclassFeature.name: Umbral Form
entries: Starting at 18th level, you can spend 6 sorcery points as a bonus action to magically transform yourself into a shadowy form. In this form, you have resistance to all damage except force and radiant damage, and you can move through other creatures and objects as if they were difficult terrain. You take 5 force damage if you end your turn inside an object.
You remain in this form for 1 minute. It ends early if you are {@condition incapacitated}, if you die, or if you dismiss it as a bonus action.

optionalfeature.name: Careful Spell
entries: When you cast a spell that forces creatures to make a saving throw, you can spend 1 sorcery point to protect a number of creatures equal to your Charisma modifier. Chosen creatures automatically succeed on their saving throw.

optionalfeature.name: Distant Spell
entries: When you cast a spell that has a range of 5 feet or greater, you can spend 1 sorcery point to double the range of the spell. When you cast a spell that has a range of touch, you can spend 1 sorcery point to make the range of the spell 30 feet.

optionalfeature.name: Elemental Spell
entries: When you cast a spell that deals acid, cold, fire, lightning, poison, or thunder damage, you spend 1 sorcery point to change it's damage type to another type from the list above.

optionalfeature.name: Empowered Spell
entries: When you roll damage for a spell, you can spend 1 sorcery point to reroll a number of the damage dice up to your Charisma modifier. You must use the new rolls. You can use Empowered Spell even if you have already used a different Metamagic during the casting of the spell.

optionalfeature.name: Esoteric Spell
entries: When you cast a spell that deals force, necrotic, psychic, or radiant damage, you spend 2 sorcery points to change it's damage type to another type from the list above.

optionalfeature.name: Extended Spell
entries: When you cast a spell that has a duration of 1 minute or longer, you can spend 1 sorcery point to double its duration, to a maximum duration of 24 hours.

optionalfeature.name: Heightened Spell
entries: When you cast a spell that forces a creature to make a saving throw to resist its effects, you can spend 3 sorcery points to give one target of the spell disadvantage on its first saving throw made against the spell.

optionalfeature.name: Kinetic Spell
entries: When you cast a spell that forces a creature to make a Strength or Dexterity saving throw, you can spend 2 sorcery points to change the initial saving throw to your choice of Strength or Dexterity.
This Metamagic only changes the initial saving throw, any subsequent saving throws the spell forces a creature to make use the spell's original saving throw.

optionalfeature.name: Quickened Spell
entries: When you cast a spell that has a casting time of 1 action, you can spend 2 sorcery points to change the casting time to 1 bonus action.

optionalfeature.name: Seeking Spell
entries: When you cast a spell that requires you to make a spell attack roll or that forces a target to make a Dexterity saving throw, you can spend 1 sorcery point to ignore the effects of half and three-quarters cover against targets of the spell.

optionalfeature.name: Subtle Spell
entries: When you cast a spell, you can spend 1 sorcery point to cast it without any somatic or verbal components.

optionalfeature.name: Tenacious Spell
entries: When you cast a spell that requires concentration, you can spend 3 sorcery points, and when you are forced to make a Constitution saving throw to maintain concentration on that spell you can choose to automatically succeed a number of times equal to your Charisma modifier (minimum of 1).

optionalfeature.name: Twinned Spell
entries: When you cast a spell that targets only one creature or object and doesn't have a range of self, you can spend a number of sorcery points equal to the spell's level to target a second target of your choice, in range, with the same spell (1 sorcery point if the spell is a cantrip). To be eligible, a spell must be incapable of targeting more than one creature or object at the spell's current level.

optionalfeature.name: Unerring Spell
entries: When you cast a spell and miss with an attack roll, you can spend 2 sorcery points to re-roll one of the attack rolls. You must use the result of the new roll.

optionalfeature.name: Unstable Spell
entries: When you cast a spell that forces a creature to make a saving throw, you can spend 3 sorcery point to change the saving throw to a random result. Roll 1d12, the spell's initial saving throw now targets the ability from the list below.

optionalfeature.name: Warped Spell
entries: When you cast a spell that forces a creature to make an Intelligence or Charisma saving throw, you can spend 3 sorcery points to change the saving throw to your choice of Intelligence or Charisma.
This Metamagic only changes the initial saving throw, any subsequent saving throws the spell forces a creature to make use the original saving throw.

optionalfeature.name: Willful Spell
entries: When you cast a spell that forces a creature to make a Constitution or Wisdom saving throw, you can spend 2 sorcery points to change the saving throw to your choice of Constitution or Wisdom.
This Metamagic only changes the initial saving throw, any subsequent saving throws the spell forces a creature to make use the original saving throw.
